info.name: REST API for Oracle Identity Cloud Service

request.description: Provides a list of allowed HTTP methods for the resource in the Access-Control-Allow-Methods header.
Provides a list of allowed HTTP methods for the resource in the Access-Control-Allow-Methods header.

item.name: Create an application with a webtier policy
Step 1 - Create a confidential client app

request.description: Create a confidential client application for use with a webtier policy.

item.name: Step 2 - Update an application with a webtier policy

request.description:
This is an example request that shows what a properly escaped WebTier Policy looks like in the request payload. 

Once you have constructed your Web Tier Policy, you need to escape it before uploading it to Oracle Identity Cloud Service. At this time, you need to manually do this using a JSON-escaping website such as:

https://www.freeformatter.com/javascript-escape.html

Copy the output from the website and use it in the request payload for the "value" attribute.

body.raw:
{
  "schemas": ["urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:oracle:idcs:App"],
  "basedOnTemplate": { "value": "CustomWebAppTemplateId" },
  "displayName": "Test Confidential Client Application",
  "description": "Confidential client application for testing purposes",
  "clientType": "confidential",
  "isOAuthClient": true,
  "allowedGrants": ["authorization_code","client_credentials","password","refresh_token","urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:jwt-bearer"],
  "redirectUris": ["https://www.myapp.com/callback"],
  "logoutUri": "https://www.myapp.com/logout",
  "postLogoutRedirectUris": ["https://www.myapp.com/"]
}

request.description:
Create a confidential client application.

Also provided as an additional example is how to create a confidential client app for use with a webtier policy.

body.raw:
{
  "schemas": ["urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:oracle:idcs:App"],
  "basedOnTemplate": { "value": "CustomWebAppTemplateId" },
  "displayName": "Test Confidential Client Application",
  "description": "Confidential client application for testing purposes",
  "clientType": "confidential",
  "isOAuthClient": true,
  "allowedGrants": ["authorization_code","client_credentials","password","refresh_token","urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:jwt-bearer"],

  "logoutUri": "https://www.myapp.com/logout",

originalRequest.description:
Create a confidential client application.

Also provided as an additional example is how to create a confidential client app for use with a webtier policy.

body.raw:
{
  "schemas": ["urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:oracle:idcs:App"],
  "basedOnTemplate": { "value": "CustomWebAppTemplateId" },
  "displayName": "Test Resource Server Application",
  "description": "Resource Server application for testing purposes",
  "isOAuthResource": true,
  "accessTokenExpiry": 3600,
  "refreshTokenExpiry": 604800,
  "allUrlSchemesAllowed": false,
  "audience": "https://api.rserver.com",
  "scopes": [
    {
      "value": "/mysettings",
      "fqs": "https://api.rserver.com/mysettings",
      "requiresConsent": true,
      "description": "Get information about your preferences"
    },{
      "value": "/post",
      "fqs": "https://api.rserver.com/post",
      "requiresConsent": true,
      "description": "Post on your behalf"
    },{
      "value": "/myprofile",
      "fqs": "https://api.rserver.com/myprofile",
      "requiresConsent": false,
      "description": "Access your profile information"
    }]
}

request.description: Create a resource server app

item.name: Create a client and resource server app

body.raw:
{
  "schemas": ["urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:oracle:idcs:App"],
  "basedOnTemplate": { "value": "CustomWebAppTemplateId" },
  "displayName": "Test Client and Resource Server",
  "description": "Client and Resource server application for testing purposes",
  "clientType": "confidential",
  "isOAuthClient": true,
  "allowedGrants": ["authorization_code","client_credentials"],
  "redirectUris": ["https://www.mytestapp.com/callback"],
  "logoutUri": "https://www.mytestapp.com/logout",
  "postLogoutRedirectUris": ["https://www.mytestapp.com/"],
  "isOAuthResource": true,
  "accessTokenExpiry": 3600,
  "refreshTokenExpiry": 604800,
  "allUrlSchemesAllowed": false,
  "audience": "https://api.mytestapp.com",
  "scopes": [
    {
      "value": "/mysettings",
      "fqs": "https://api.mytestapp.com/mysettings",
      "requiresConsent": true,
      "description": "Get information about your preferences"
    },{
      "value": "/post",
      "fqs": "https://api.mytestapp.com/post",
      "requiresConsent": true,
      "description": "Post on your behalf"
    },{
      "value": "/myprofile",
      "fqs": "https://api.mytestapp.com/myprofile",
      "requiresConsent": false,
      "description": "Access your profile information"
    }]
}

request.description: Create a client and resource server application

body.raw:
{
  "schemas": ["urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:oracle:idcs:App"],
  "basedOnTemplate": { "value": "CustomWebAppTemplateId" },
  "displayName": "Test SAML Application",
  "description": "SAML application for testing purposes",
  "clientType": "trusted",
  "isOAuthClient": true,
  "allowedGrants": ["authorization_code","client_credentials","password","refresh_token","urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:jwt-bearer"],
  "redirectUris": ["https://www.myapp.com/callback"],
  "logoutUri": "https://www.myapp.com/logout",
  "postLogoutRedirectUris": ["https://www.myapp.com/"]
}

request.description:
An OAuth client application is an HTTP client that can acquire, and then use an access token. There are three types of OAuth client applications that you can create: Confidential, Trusted, and Public. Both the confidential and trusted client apps are specified by using CustomWebAppTemplateId as the value for the basedOnTemplate attribute. 

Note: If you are using the optional name attribute in your request, be sure to use only alphanumeric characters and the underscore ( _ ) character in the value.

body.raw:
{
  "schemas": ["urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:oracle:idcs:App"],
  "basedOnTemplate": { "value": "CustomBrowserMobileTemplateId" },
  "displayName": "Test Public Client Application",
  "description": "Public client application for testing purposes",
  "clientType": "public",
  "isOAuthClient": true,
  "allowedGrants": ["authorization_code","implicit"],
  "redirectUris": ["https://www.myapp.com/callback"],
  "logoutUri": "https://www.myapp.com/logout",
  "postLogoutRedirectUris": ["https://www.myapp.com/"]
}

request.description:
An OAuth client application is an HTTP client that can acquire, and then use an access token. There are three types of OAuth client applications that you can create: Confidential, Trusted, and Public.

The public client app is specified by using CustomBrowserMobileTemplateId as the value for the basedOnTemplate attribute.

For all internal and default resources, the security question ID for out of the box default security questions is defaulted to text. After you create a new security question, the system generate a numeric ID.

item.name: Delete a security question - System Generated ID

request.description:
For all internal and default resources, the security question ID for out of the box default security questions is defaulted to text. After you create a new security question, the system generates a numeric ID.

This example shows a system generated ID as the security question ID.

item.name: Remove all authentication factors for a user

request.description:
Remove all authentication factor channels for a user. Deleting all of the enrolled MFA channels includes a user's registered devices, bypass codes created for or by the user, any trusted devices for the user, and any security questions registered for the user.

request.description: Users can use /Me to replace their profile information.
A user can use the /Me endpoint to update profile information. This example shows the request to add a single attribute.
A user can use the /Me endpoint to update profile information. This example shows the request to update a single attribute.
A user can use the /Me endpoint to update profile information. This example shows the request to update multiple attributes.

A user can use /MePasswordChanger to change their own password.

To test this endpoint, use an access token for an application with the Me approle defined.

item.name: Email Verification
item.description:
The examples in this folder show the steps that a user may take to verify their email.

Step 1 - A user makes a change to their email 
Step 2 - A user initiates self service email verification
Step 3 - The user token is obtained
Step 4 - The user self-verifies their email address.

item.name: Step 1: User Makes a Change to Their Info

request.description:
A user can use /Me to replace their recovery email.

To test this endpoint, use an access token for an application with the Me approle defined.

item.name: Step 2: User Initiates Self-Service Email Verification

request.description:
A user can use /MeEmailVerifier to initiate self-service email verification for either their primary or recovery email address.

To test this endpoint, use an access token for an application with the Me approle defined.

After Step 2, an email is sent to the user with a link. The user clicks the link, which sends the user token, and the UI invokes the /MeEmailVerified endpoint using that user token.

Use Step 3 to get the user token (since Postman can't access emails).

This is the final step of verifying a new email address or an updated email address. Validates the token and then marks the recovery email as verified.

To test this endpoint, use an access token for an application with the Me approle defined.

item.name: Password Reset
item.description: The steps in this folder cover the endpoints used in the process that a user goes through to reset their password.

item.name: Step 1: Retrieve password recovery options to get masked email value

request.description:
This is the first step in the password reset process.

A user can use /MePasswordRecoveryOptionRetriever to retrieve their password recovery options by email.

Use the OAuth Client App access token with the following approles assigned:

Identity Domain Administrator
Me
Verify Email
Forgot Password

The masked email option is found in the options section of the response:

{
    "options": [
        {
            "type": "email",
            "value": "****@example.com"
        }
    ],

Initiates the forgotten password process for the user, which sends a reset password email.

Use the OAuth Client App access token with the following approles assigned:

Identity Domain Administrator
Me
Verify Email
Forgot Password

After step 2, an email is sent to the user with a link. The user clicks the link, which sends the user token. The UI then invokes the /MePasswordReset endpoint using that user token.

Use Step 3 to get the user token (since Postman can't access emails).
Resets the user's password by validating the token.

item.name: Favorite or Unfavorite an App
item.description: The steps in this folder describe how a user accesses their apps and then favorites or unfavorites an app.

request.description:
Use /MyApps to search for the ID of an app that a user has access to.

To test this endpoint, use an access token for an application with the Me approle defined.

item.name: Step 2: Favorite or unfavorite an app

request.description:
Use /MyAppFavoriteSetter to set the "favorite" attribute value to "true" or "false" to favorite or unfavorite a specific app.

To test this endpoint, use an access token for an application with the Me approle defined.

item.name: MFA Self Service
item.description: The endpoints in this folder are self-service endpoints for Multi-Factor Authentication.

item.name: Validate my security questions and answers

request.description:
Users can use /MeSecurityQuestionAnswerValidator to validate their security questions and answers. 

The questionIds for the default security questions that come with Oracle Identity Cloud Service are:

FavoriteFood
FavoriteToy
ChildhoodHero
FavoriteTeam
FirstPet
FirstManager
MaidenName
FavoriteTeacher
FavoriteBook
FirstMovie
FirstTimeOnPlane
DreamJob
FirstCar
FavoriteMovie
FavoriteSportsPerson
Users can use /MeSecurityQuestionsRetriever to retrieve their security questions.
Users can use /MyBypassCodes to create a bypass code.
Users can use /MyBypassCodes to search for a bypass code.
Users can use /MyBypassCodes to search for bypass codes.

item.name: Search for Bypass Codes Using POST

request.description: Users can use /MyBypassCodes to search for bypass codes using POST.
Users can use /MyBypassCodes to delete a bypass code.
A user can use /MyDevices to search for one or more devices associated with their account.
A user can use /MyDevices to search for a device associated with their account.

A user can use /MyDevices to update a device associated with their account. 

Each patch operation object MUST have exactly one "op" member, whose value indicates the operation to perform and MAY be one of "add", "remove", or "replace".
A user can use /MyDevices to delete a device associated with their account.
A user can use /MyTrustedUserAgents to search for their trusted devices that are used for Multi-Factor Authentication.
A user can use /MyTrustedUserAgents to search for a trusted device that is used for Multi-Factor Authentication.
A user can use /MyTrustedUserAgents to delete a trusted device that is used for Multi-Factor Authentication.

item.name: Remove all of my authentication factors

request.description: A user can use /MyAuthenticationFactorsRemover to delete all of their enrolled Multi-Factor Authentication channels. This includes registered devices, bypass codes created, any trusted devices for the user, and any security questions registered.

A user can use /Me for self-profile management.

To test this endpoint, use an access token for an application with the Me approle defined.

The user can use the /MePasswordRecoveryOptionRetriever endpoint to retrieve their password recovery options. The user receives an email. 

Use the OAuth Client App access token with the following approles assigned:

Identity Domain Administrator
Me
Verify Email
Forgot Password

A user can use /MyAccesses to view and search for Apps that they have access to. This endpoint supports filtering by App attributes.

To test this endpoint, use an access token for an application with the Me approle defined.

A user can use /MyApps to view and search for Apps that are granted to them. This endpoint supports filtering by App attributes.

To test this endpoint, use an access token for an application with the Me approle defined.

count = number of entries retrieved
startIndex = index for search result
attributes = comma separated list of values retrieved in a search
filter = add a filter criteria to the search using attributes, values, and operators
